awd_titl_txt: RCN: Phenotype Ontology Research Coordination Network
awd_abstract_narration:
Knowledge of how an organism looks, behaves and functions, i.e., its "phenotype", is central to interpreting the interaction of underlying genes and environmental effects.  Representing phenotype in a way that can be linked to thousands of molecular genetic and environmental databases, however, remains difficult. The goal of this project is to establish a network of experts on plant and animal phenotypes and on computer representation methods (ontologies) from communities that are independently developing ways to represent and share phenotypic data. Through this Research Coordination Network, scientists will be brought together and their activities coordinated to:  (1) develop standards and best practices for accurate phenotype representations; (2) build key reference ontologies for plants, vertebrates, and arthropods; and (3) cross reference these ontologies so that key data can be easily shared and accessed. 

Coordinating scientific efforts so that effective linkages are built into databases from the outset is an efficient and economical mechanism to develop a data network. Plants and animals show complex integration across genes, phenotype and environment, and a network of these data will enable rapid scientific discovery and progress. This project also will reach out to scientists who can use the data, help them link to it, and educate their communities about these computational methods and their utility.

inst.inst_name: University of South Dakota Main Campus

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of South Dakota Main Campus

por.por_cntn:
Knowledge of how an organism looks, behaves and functions, i.e., its associated phenotypes, is central to interpreting the interaction of underlying genes and environmental effects and to understanding the evolutionary history and relationships between organisms. Representing phenotypes in a way that can be linked to genetic and environmental databases, however, is challenging. The primary goal of this RCN was to establish a network of experts on plant and animal phenotypes, informatics, and computer representation methods (ontologies) from communities that are independently developing ways to represent, share, and analyze phenotypic data. Through a series of summit meetings, smaller working groups and workshops, virtual meetings, and through collaborative lab exchanges and meeting presentations, the network:

  • Established best practices for ontology development and phenotype representation standards

  • Developed resources (e.g., high-level ontologies and databases) that bridge research communities working on phenotypes

  • Disseminated knowledge about ontologies and their roles in phenotype research

  • Trained current and future phenotype researchers in relevant informatics

The network grew to include well over 400 researchers, postdocs, and students from many countries, including experts on model organism research, biodiversity, neuroscience, plants and agriculture, and informatics. The intellectual merits of the network resulted in research papers that describe new, high level ontologies, ontologies that have been refined based on working group activities, novel approaches to representing complex phenotypes, research stimulated or facilitated by the network, and at least a dozen grant proposals for research on phenotypes. Examples of products include: (1) The Arthropod Working Group generated high level classes that connect knowledge of Drosophila (a heavily researched model organism) to phenotype data generated on Hymenoptera (an extraordinarily diverse taxon that includes several model organisms) and soon to Coleoptera (beetles), Neuroptera (lacewings), Araneae (spiders), and many other arthropod taxa; (2) the Behavior Working Group began integration of two important ontologies (the Animal Behavior Ontology and the NeuroBehavior Ontology); (3) the Vertebrate Working Group members put their broad knowledge into a format that bridges research across many groups and systems (e.g., bone, cartilage, the neural crest); (4) the Plant Working Group assembled and analyzed a large phenotype dataset (6,361 phenotype (Entity-Quality) statements describing mutant phenotypes associated to 2,744 genes) of six well-studied plant species (Arabidopsis, rice, maize, soybean, Medicago, and tomato) in part as a demonstration of the utility of these approaches.

The broader impacts of this international network are diverse and include key ontologies that are openly accessible and broadly used across medical, agricultural, and basic research communities. Further, the summer courses, annual meetings, workshops, and collaborative exchanges involved the training of dozens of students and postdocs in ontology development and visionary uses, and resulted in the publication of best-practices guides and how-to manuals for making phenotype data accessible for computation.

Finally, the goals of the Phenotype Ontology Research Coordination Network were met in that a diverse, cohesive, and communicative network of scientists from academic and private institutions was established, and resources were developed that facilitate and accelerate research on computable phenotypes. The desire to maintain and grow this network beyond the funded timeframe is strong evidence of the utility and timeliness of this work.


Last Modified: 01/06/2017
Modified by: Wasila Dahdul
